speech.para: In April this year the Intellectual Property and Competition Review Committee released its report into parallel importing and recommended removing the restrictions on parallel imports. Specifically, it recommended that the restrictions should be retained only if they advanced the goals of copyright and the intellectual property system more generally in ways that could only be cost effectively secured by these restrictions. Consumers are now able to buy music, videos, books and computer software direct from the Internet. What this does is erode a domestic distribution monopoly. In Europe, parallel import restrictions are banned. The committee went on to conclude that doing this would not damage the Australian economy. Lifting the restrictions would reduce the price of books and software. Computer games are currently 33 per cent more expensive in Australia than in the United States. Paperback books were 50 per cent higher in price than in the United States and 12 per cent over the UK price. There are some business software programs and popular personal computer games which are also higher. In 1998 Australia lifted the restrictions on the parallel imports of CDs and the price did fall from $A31 to $A24. The advantages of removing the restriction are cheaper products and no wait for books and software to become available. When New Zealand did this, the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research found that the prices of CDs and books were as cheap as anywhere in the world.

The government will also maintain antipiracy measures. There is no evidence in New Zealand that removing the parallel import restrictions has increased piracy. The same arguments that were raised about CDs have been raised about books and video games. Piracy is occurring now and piracy is independent of parallel importing. For example, the Napster web site allows people to download music from the Internet. In July 2000, Software Engineering Australia supported the government's initiative, saying it would help e-commerce and maximise innovation and creativity. The restrictions have prevented Australian retailers getting the same price as overseas e-commerce retailers. Therefore they have to charge more online. This has been an impediment for Australian based e-commerce retailers. In short, Australians should be able to have books, software, printed music and magazines as soon as they are available anywhere in the world. I encourage the Attorney-General to release his legislation to amend the Copyright Act as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —The member for Sturt wants this House to recognise that easing restrictions on parallel importing will result in cheaper prices for Australian consumers. The government has scrapped parallel import provisions on music and CDs—and have prices dropped? No. He wants us to acknowledge that easing restrictions on parallel importing will allow Australian consumers to enjoy a greater range of products. Can the members for Sturt and Boothby really be believed on this issue? What benefits will there be for Australian industry, for small business and for jobs? None. The member for Sturt would also have us believe that easing restrictions on parallel importing improves product innovation and development. So does it encourage and enhance investment and create business opportunities for Australian companies? No. Indeed, a big question mark hangs over the government's interest in parallel importation.

speech.para: I suspect this is nothing more than another instalment of the coalition's economic rationalist policies so blindly followed by the member for Sturt. What is his motivation for this? All the evidence so far, certainly where I come from, does not support his grandstanding on this issue. Remember that supporters of the legislation to allow parallel imports of music CDs told us it would drive down the cost of CDs. There is no substantive evidence to suggest it has. In fact, the free-falling Aussie dollar has actually resulted in increased prices for imported music. As I was told at the weekend by an employee of a music store in my electorate, all it has done is put the squeeze on small independent retailers even further because they do not have the buying power of the major chains. Is that good for small business?

I note comments from the Australian Music Retailers Association in its submission to a Senate committee report regarding parallel imports of sound recordings under the Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997, which said:

quote.para: Small business retailers have been deserted by the Coalition government, in spite of its recognition that small business is the `engine room' of the economy. Government policy in this matter actively works to destroy a section of that `engine room'.

speech.para: It goes on that it:

quote.para: ... will have a disastrous effect on small music businesses while offering little or no ultimate benefit to Australian consumers.

speech.para: That is quite prophetic, it would seem. Is it good for the Australian music industry which, because of this government's dismissive attitude toward copyright entitlements, now faces the threat of cheap, often pirated imports? As my musical colleague the member for Bendigo asked, are these anticopyright policies promoted by the coalition's obsession with parallel importing good for Australian musicians, who are getting less in royalties for their work? I think not.
I refer again to the Senate report and comments from the manager of Savage Garden, Mr John Woodruff. He said:

quote.para: If you own the rights to something and you pay for them and you develop them and you promote them, you should be able to protect them ... If any of you owned or controlled exclusive Australian rights to any property, be it Nike or McDonalds, and a licensee from an international territory was allowed to export into this country over the top of you, then you would never invest again. I find this argument astoundingly simple and cannot understand which part of this the Coalition does not comprehend.

speech.para: Groups like Savage Garden—I would suggest they would be a very Savage Garden after this—are paying the price for this type of legislation. As usual, this government is raising more questions than it has answers to. Two years after allowing parallel imports of CDs, the government now plans to do the same for books and computer software. Again, the promise of cheaper prices for software is questionable. But to do the same for books has quite rightly raised the ire of our paper manufacturing and book printing industries. I know of the concerns in my electorate and the likely consequences for paper making mills at Wesley Vale and Burnie. It would have a significant impact on their businesses. I am advised that losses in paper production nationally would amount to some $11 million a year. It would also cost jobs in the paper making industry. Where I come from we cannot afford to lose one job.

Unlike the coalition's approach, under Labor's policy Australia's music industry, paper manufacturers, publishers, and computer software and video game distributors will maintain exclusive copyright of their goods, but only as long as they exercise that right to the benefit of Australian consumers—that is, a use it or lose it policy. That means that local copyright holders are bound to market their goods 30 days after international release or they lose their exclusive right of import. The same applies to goods being made available for purchase under the 90-day rule. That is responsible parallel importation policy as distinct from the economic-rationalism-gone-mad policies of this government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mrs Gash)—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—I move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) remembers the extraordinary deeds of John Simpson Kirkpatrick who, with his donkeys, rescued injured above and beyond the call of duty until he was himself killed; and
(2) implores the government to award a posthumous Victoria Cross of Australia to “Simpson” in accordance with the wishes of his WWI commanding officers and overwhelming public demand.

speech.para: This matter was first brought to my attention by a constituent, Mr Ken Johnson of Belmont, and has since received widespread support throughout Australia and from overseas, with many people seizing the opportunity to sign petitions. Every Anzac Day we as Australians turn our thoughts to those who have given their lives and suffered in war so that we might live in peace. `Lest we forget,' we say; and yet, in a way, we have forgotten. We have forgotten to properly recognise a man who has become the very epitome of Anzac: Private Jack Simpson Kirkpatrick. Jack Kirkpatrick was not born in Australia but he was born with the larrikin spirit. A member of the merchant marine, he jumped ship after hearing that war had been declared and, fearing that as a deserter he would not be allowed to enlist in the army, enlisted as Jack Simpson on 23 August 1914.

Jack was sent to Gallipoli with the 3rd Field Ambulance as a stretcher bearer. He soon found that, with the assistance of donkeys, he was able to rescue injured soldiers single-handedly. In the last 24 days of his life, he rescued over 300 people while under direct enemy fire. That is 12 to 13 people a day. You may think that one such rescue would be enough to see a man awarded the highest possible honour, and you would be right. But for Jack it was not to be. He was officially recommended for the Victoria Cross on 3 June 1915 by his commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel Alfred Sutton, who wrote of Simpson:

quote.para: It is difficult to get evidence of any one act to justify the Victoria Cross—the fact is he did so many.

speech.para: Colonel Monash—later General Sir John Monash—in a submission to Divisional Headquarters said of him:

quote.para: Simpson knew no fear and moved unconcernedly amid shrapnel and rifle fire, steadily carrying out his self-imposed task day by day ...

speech.para: Why was the Victoria Cross refused? Because of a mistake in the application. In 1967 Australian leaders sent a petition to the British War Office, asking that this tragic error be rectified. Again the award of the Victoria Cross was denied, on the ground that it would set a dangerous precedent. In fact, just such a precedent had already been set with the posthumous award of the Victoria Cross to two British officers 28 years after their deaths.

In my campaign to have Simpson awarded the VC, I contacted other members on both sides of the House, and I thank those who gave me their support. I also wrote to the Prime Minister to seek his support. I was astounded to find that that support was not forthcoming, neither was a reply. Instead, I got a letter from Bill Heffernan, on behalf of the Prime Minister, which said:

quote.para: Despite the admiration and affection that Australians have for Simpson, it is no longer possible to support further recognition as you have proposed. There were so many Australians who served heroically during World War I, many making the ultimate sacrifice. To now single out one brave soldier of this period would not be appropriate. The judgements of commanding officers of the time on how Simpson's service was recognised should be respected and their decisions allowed to stand.

speech.para: That is exactly the point: the judgments of the commanding officers of the time should be respected—Simpson should be awarded the Victoria Cross. Every Australian schoolchild learns of the brave deeds of Simpson, who along with his beloved donkeys risked his life on countless occasions. A visit to the Australian War Memorial Museum is testament to the high esteem in which Simpson is held. Even the museum shop sells many items honouring Simpson and his donkey, such as the figurine I have in my hand and the badge I am wearing on my lapel. I have here a few comments from ordinary Australians who have signed an Internet petition. From Victoria:

quote.para: How sad it is that we have to sign a petition for this ... Hang your heads in shame.

speech.para: From New South Wales:

quote.para: My grandfather served in Gallipoli in 1915, was wounded and returned to Australia. He always talked to my father about Simpson and his donkey and my father passed these stories to me ... For him to be awarded Australia's first home-grown Victoria Cross can only add to the honour of any future Australian VC winners.

speech.para: From Tasmania:

quote.para: A true Anzac hero is not recognised for his bravery, courage and great self-sacrifice. Wake up you politicians, and give him the medal he deserves!

speech.para: From the ACT:

quote.para: Surely we can recognise Simpson, who gave his life for others. His actions typify the most noble of man's qualities.

speech.para: From South Australia:

quote.para: I believe Simpson's valour should be recognised.

speech.para: From the United States:

quote.para: As the son of a World War I, 8th Light Horse Regiment member, I too add my name. Simpson's recognition has been too long in coming.

speech.para: From the United Kingdom:

quote.para: How can modern day politicians possibly see themselves better versed in the events surrounding John Simpson's actions than the officers who recommended him for the VC?

speech.para: And, finally, from Turkey:

quote.para: As an Australian living near the Gallipoli battlefields, I can say that Simpson's grave is the most visited grave. Most visited because if there is just one Anzac that Australians know, it is Simpson.

speech.para: As I said, these are just a few comments, and the support for my campaign continues to build. Today I received a letter from Mr John Kershaw, from Fleetwood, England. He is a member of the Gallipoli Association, and he wrote to express his support and admiration for Jack Simpson, whom he calls `a very brave man'. Let us continue to bow our heads with pride on Anzac Day. It is a shame that, after all this time, we cannot properly recognise one of our greatest Anzacs. If the Anzacs were here today, I'll bet there would be quite a few who would be surprised that we have not listened to our own officers of the day. They would wonder why we have not done the right thing and properly recognised our hero.

Jack Simpson is not the only brave Australian who deserves our recognition and admiration. There have been many—Able Seaman Edward `Teddy' Sheean is one who springs to mind—but I do believe it is entirely appropriate to begin with Simpson and for him to receive the first Australian Victoria Cross. I would like each of you to take with you today this poem, sent to me from Western Australia and written by one of Simpson's fellow soldiers at Gallipoli:

quote.para: Along the tumbled hills that lie
Beside the oldest sea of all
The Diggers saw him passing by
And heard his answer to their call
And well they knew him, although to
But few of them his name was known
And broken was a mateship true
When Simpson's donk came back alone
He sleeps beside the sapphire wave,
But ever shall his spirit live
He knew not men would call him brave
When giving all he had to give
He'd take a wounded cobber's weight
In arms that ease and hope would bring
And proved himself a dinkum mate
When mateship was a living thing
Again the scrub has over-run
The hillside paths where Simpson went
Whereon his splendid deeds were done
Whereon his glorious hours were spent
But there's a roadway that shall last
That no wild growth can ever claim:
The roadway up which Simpson passed
To the eternal halls of fame.

speech.para: Just think about those heartfelt words for a moment. Prime Minister, how can you not open up your heart and correct the injustices of the past? I call on you to do the right thing and to do everything in your power to see that Jack Simpson Kirkpatrick is posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross. The deeds of Jack Simpson have earned this, the memory of the Anzacs demand it, and the Australian people expect no less.

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt about it: John Simpson Kirkpatrick, `the man with the donkey', is immortalised in the Australian spirit, and he certainly does represent the Anzac fighting spirit and the tragedy of Gallipoli. He is well known from the legends that have grown since that day back in May 1915 when he died with a sniper's bullet through the heart. His efforts in bringing the wounded out on his donkeys—which he procured following his landing at Gallipoli on Anzac Day—have lived on through the course of my lifetime and through that of my father.

speech.para: In that regard, the member for Shortland is certainly tapping into a great sense of national pride in Simpson and what he represents. In many ways, I think that the concept of giving Simpson a Victoria Cross downgrades the status that he already enjoys in Australian hearts and minds. I would suggest that it is a matter of great frustration to Australians, 85 years after the fact, that no government at that time—including the Labor government when all of these deeds took place all those years ago—and no government since has seen fit to review this. One would suspect there must be some reason why this man, this legend in my grandfather's lifetime, has not been dealt with properly.

It is my understanding that the VC for Australia accords recognition to persons who perform acts of the most conspicuous gallantry, acts of valour or self-sacrifice, or who display extreme devotion to duty in the presence of the enemy. Those are the criteria. Nominations are to be supported by signed statements of at least three witnesses of the act for which the award is recommended. Wherever possible, these statements should be on oath, and awards are to be made with the approval of the Queen by an instrument signed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister for Defence. The other problem is that it is very difficult to review any particular incident of World War I and to reverse the decisions taken by the commanders without creating a precedent for unwanted and perhaps divisive comparisons to be drawn between these hindsight awards and those recommended and granted at the time by those most involved. Recommendations for decorations are best made by the commanders on the spot, who certainly have a better knowledge of the totality of the circumstances surrounding an incident than those who conduct a review many years later. That is the brief that I have from the department.

I do not want to be accused of attacking motherhood—I am not intending to do so—but it is important to discover the reasons why this matter relating to Kirkpatrick, otherwise known as Simpson, the man with the donkey, was not dealt with. I am led to believe that the closure of the End of War List—those who were recommended for some sort of award from the First World War—occurred some six months after Armistice Day all those years ago and that therein lies the problem. Whilst I agree with the sentiment of giving awards, medals and so forth, I am also very gravely concerned that, in doing so, we are breaking down the award structure and the prestige attached to the Victoria Cross for Australia.

The VC for Australia was established in 1991 under the previous government. It is the pre-eminent wartime decoration. It should not be given lightly. It continues on the tradition of the Imperial VC, instituted by Queen Victoria in 1856, and I am indebted to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Scott, who is at the table, when he says it is still the same Victoria Cross. In fact, the conditions established by the Keating government or the Hawke government—things changed quickly in those days—are exactly the same. They are mirror conditions to those laid down in 1920.

The fact is that Simpson was posthumously mentioned in despatches for his action. As the member for Shortland said, there are a variety of records of what occurred in those days. There certainly are those who say there were many acts of great bravery that occurred, and there may or may not have been a clerical error which led to Simpson being mentioned in despatches rather than being awarded a VC—and I believe that it does not happen that you get two big awards for one big thing. Therein lies the difficulty with the sentiment being somewhat detached from the reality of dealing with these issues.

But I have to say that in my own electorate there is greater pressure on me to address a number of other factors. This government since coming to power has done a lot of the housekeeping of a more contemporary nature than the Simpson matter. The Far Eastern Strategic Reserve was a matter that needed to be addressed, and Minister Scott and Prime Minister John Howard have dealt with it and have delivered a greater sense of justice and outcome to those, mainly men, who were involved in that particular action than had been the case before. Likewise, World War II veterans, who for so many years after the end of that war juggled their paperwork to qualify for gold card status and the assistance that it brought, now find that, as World War II veterans aged over 70 with the qualifying service, they are being well facilitated by this government.

Of course, it would be quite wrong for me to say that all is complete. As a private member in this place it would be wrong for me to not reflect upon the next set of things that I think we should be looking at. The gold card is one matter. Korean and Vietnam veterans aged over 70 who have had a similar qualifying service—although, of course, in a different theatre to the World War II veterans—rightly expect, and I believe should receive, the same treatment. They are over the age of 70 and have qualified from a service point of view. I believe that it should be not only World War II veterans but also those aged over 70, and I have had reason to write to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to express just that view and I will continue to do so. Likewise, I believe that the National Service Medal needs to be looked at. There is a proposal from those who were engaged in national service since 1951. The 50th anniversary is next year. Those men and women who were prepared to—perhaps a little against their will—serve Australia through national service in times of war should be identified.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act is the most generous in the world—that is well understood—but there are, of course, other claims still outstanding. I look forward to hearing more about the claims from those nurses who went to Vietnam who believe that, having served Australian troops in that theatre, they likewise may need some additional assistance. Seeing the minister is here, it gives me a chance to mention another matter, that is, the civilian war prisoners of Japan. There is an organisation based in part in my electorate, which has my full support, that represents the remnants of the 1,200 Australian citizens who were held as internees by the Japanese during World War II—women and children who now need support and who are not recognised under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The number of people who are now represented by this organisation totals just 400. These people were in countries in South-East Asia invaded by Japan. They were interned as prisoners of war and suffered the difficulties and traumas of those days and are still carrying a lot of the psychological, emotional and medical scars. I understand that the Japanese are considering matters and that the appellant court in Tokyo will be making a judgment on this in early 2001. The members of that organisation spread throughout Australia will be rightly looking to see what the appellant court does.

I raise these matters in the context of this motion from the member for Shortland to try to illustrate the fact that the agenda on matters to do with veterans' affairs is very full. Every time the government addresses one of the issues and deals with one of the problems that have been left undone despite the generosity of the system, another one very quickly and readily takes its place. The Simpson matter is another one of those on the list. I could not rule out that the centenary of Simpson's death might in fact incur a revisitation of this, but who is to know? At the end of the day, though, our Veterans' Entitlements Act and the act which governs imperial awards and honours and national awards and honours in this country are very complete and should not be the only recourse for celebrating the contribution of an individual. John Simpson Kirkpatrick is in Australian folklore. He is an Australian legend. He is in badge work. He is in our hearts and in our minds. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to be able to speak to the motion proposed by the member for Shortland. Private John Simpson Kirkpatrick, the man with the donkey, was a true hero in all senses of the word. Those of us lucky enough to have spent time visiting the area of Turkey known to all Australians as Gallipoli, marvel at the feats of bravery displayed by Australian and New Zealand soldiers over 85 years ago.

speech.para: Gallipoli holds a special place in my heart. My father, Robert Quick, fought there as a member of the 7th Battalion. As a child I listened to his stories of what transpired in a place that seemed so far away and read with interest his notes and diary excerpts. It was not until 1995, on the 80th anniversary of Anzac Day, and I was privileged to actually visit Gallipoli that the whole Anzac story fell into place for me. Wandering across the battlefields, exploring the trenches at Lone Pine, The Nek and Quinn's Post, clambering Shrapnel Gully and wading out into Anzac Cove—all things my father had done as an 18-year-old—to experience first-hand the impossible task given to the Anzacs, one cannot but be struck by the bravery of all concerned.

The motion before us seeks to posthumously award the Victoria Cross to one of the bravest of the brave, a fearless young man who served his king and country without any thought for his own life. As Patsy Adam Smith says on page 122 of her wonderful book The Anzacs:

quote.para: There had to be a hero. The people demanded one. Wholesale slaughter, wholesale bravery are too immense for the puny human imagination to grasp; they overwhelm and depress the collective mind. So there was a hero. But this one was different. This was a man as redolent as a gum tree, as Australian as a kangaroo, a real colonial spirit. He had scarcely begun his task when he was killed, and with the slower communications of the time, he was dead before Australia knew he was alive. But they were sure that they knew what a hero looked like.

speech.para: One of the tragedies of Simpson, the man with the donkey, is that most, if not all, Australians were taught to revere him as a sort of hero in the fictional mould. Private Simpson was a real man and, when he died, real men wept in the sight of others.

My father never had the privilege of meeting Simpson. Dad arrived at Anzac Cove on 26 May, a week after Simpson's death. My dad, however, spoke in glowing terms of the men of the field ambulance who worked tirelessly to assist the many wounded to safety and treatment. Simpson was a legend at Gallipoli and an inspiration to all who had the honour to serve there. C.E.W. Bean wrote of Simpson:

quote.para: On the night of April 25th he annexed the donkey, and each day and half of every night he worked continuously between the head of Monash Gully and the beach, his donkey carrying a brassard round its forehead and a wounded man on its back. Simpson escaped death so many times that he was completely fatalistic. The deadly sniping down the valley and the most furious shrapnel fire never stopped him. The Colonel of his ambulance, recognising the value of his work, allowed him to carry on as a completely separate unit. On May 19, he went up the valley past the water guard where he generally had his breakfast, but it was not ready. `Never mind,' he called, `give me a good dinner when I come back.' He never came back. With two patients he was coming down the creek bed when he was hit through the heart, both the wounded men being wounded again.

speech.para: It is ridiculous in the extreme to believe that one of the finest and bravest young men ever to serve in the Anzac campaign was denied a Victoria Cross on a technicality. No award was made to Simpson, as one single act of valour was what the citation called for. It is interesting to note some of the comments of the soldiers of the time. One of them there said:

quote.para: I can honestly say that these lads performed deeds of great heroism and utterly fearless bravery sufficient to warrant the issue all round of VCs, but nobody of high enough military rank saw them. We, their mates, saw it all.

speech.para: I would like to endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Shortland. I think it is time, despite the fact that this man was a legend in his own lifetime, that we got through all the bureaucratic BS and red tape and issued this man, as we head towards the Centenary of Federation, with the award that he so rightly deserves.

talk.start.para: —The member for Franklin talked about the need to find meaning amidst the killing at Gallipoli and a nation's need for heroes. There is a sense in which, when we talk about Private John Simpson Kirkpatrick, we are really talking not just about a man or about a soldier but about a nation's idea of itself. We meddle in this question at our own peril because Simpson has certainly assumed the role of the pre-eminent Australian soldier icon. There is no military figure who would be half as well known, from the most humble private to the most celebrated general as this one man and, curiously, his donkey. I think there is something characteristically Australian about the way in which Simpson has been canonised in our culture. Frankly, it is difficult to rouse much enthusiasm to oppose a motion such as the one that the honourable member has put. It would be like opposing a motion that we should be more grateful to our mothers or that we should tell our children we love them. Simpson is clearly an enormous figure in the national psyche of the Australian people, and so he should be.

speech.para: On 19 May 1915, 42,000 Turkish soldiers resolved to make one last effort to blast 17,356 Anzacs back into the ocean at Gallipoli. They began with the most sustained attack of machine gun artillery and sniper fire. The day saw intense fighting in which 168 Anzacs were killed—and we ought to recall that it was a day in which 3,000 Turks were also killed. It was on that day that this man, who had led something of a charmed life, made his last trip up the pass, up Shrapnel Gully, to collect the wounded. His reputation had grown over the previous 24 days because of his apparent indifference to fear. He was fired upon frequently. In fact, the donkey which was eventually the last one was one of several. These donkeys, which were used as water carriers, had been shot from underneath the troops they were rescuing. But he carried on with a great sense of humour and a lightness of spirit in the face of this incredible danger. In fact, Monash said in his citation that Simpson knew no fear and moved unconcernedly amid shrapnel and rifle fire, steadily carrying out his self-imposed task day by day. He frequently earned the applause of the personnel for his many fearless rescues of wounded men from areas subject to rifle and shrapnel fire.

Whenever you scratch the surface of a legend, you find the complexity of the human character underneath. Certainly Simpson was a man whose distinction in his last 24 days of life on earth was something of a contrast to his earlier 19-odd years. As one of the previous speakers mentioned, he did desert the British Merchant Navy at Newcastle. It appears that his principal objective in joining the AIF was to return to England. He was absolutely radical in his politics. He hated class distinctions of any kind. He described himself as a rabid socialist. There must be some question of whether he would have accepted a Victoria Cross under those circumstances. Nonetheless, through the mix of this alloy, through this alloy of human nobility and frailty, emerges this man to whom, whether or not this government decides to award the Victoria Cross, the Australian people have awarded the honour which it will forever be his to retain, and that is that he is the most celebrated, the most emblematic, the most iconic figure in Australian military history.

talk.start.para: (Mrs Gash)—Order! The time allotted for private members business has expired. The debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

(Mrs Gash)—Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator Faulkner has been discharged from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and that Senator Crowley has been appointed a member of the committee.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —In this grievance debate I want to talk about the shoddy treatment Australians receive from the major banks. Supposedly in the quest for efficiencies and cost savings, but in reality in the push for bigger and bigger profits, the major banks turn their backs on the very customers whose loyalty has helped to build the strong banking sector we see today. We see in the media almost daily that Australian banks have announced further branch closures while recording gigantic profits. In the financial year ending June 1999 the ANZ Banking Group declared a profit of $1.48 billion, the Commonwealth Bank $1.42 billion, Westpac $1.46 billion and the National Australia Bank $2.821 billion. That is a combined total profit of $7.2 billion. These figures prove that the banking sector is secure and is able to show enormous profits even in what it claims are difficult times.

speech.para: What is not secure is the loyalty and commitment of the banks to the people of Australia. In spite of these fabulous profit levels, the major banks are turning their backs on their customers—and in particular rural communities—by closing branches and walking away, in some cases leaving a trail of devastation. There is one thing that small country towns can always bank on—the threat of being turned into a town with no bank, and a town with no bank is often a town with no future. Many smaller communities that lose their bank branches wither and die because people from surrounding districts have to go elsewhere for banking services and almost always undertake their household shopping purchases in the same larger areas that still have bank branches. So all the other small businesses contract and the general community suffers a major reduction in living standards, all because the major banks decide to turn their backs on people who live in country and remote areas. Australia's bigger banks do not understand the term `good corporate citizens' and would rate at the bottom of the list.

In June 1993 there were 7,064 bank branches operating throughout Australia. In June 1999 there were 5,358. That is a reduction of 1,706 branches. This means that one in four bank branches throughout Australia have closed during that period. That is, 284 banks closed per year—on average, one for every working day of every week of every year. More than one-third of these branches were in small country towns—that is, one country bank branch closed every three days. Some country towns saw as many as four or five bank branches disappear completely. The job losses in banking have been just as phenomenal. Some 40,000 jobs have been shed in the 10 years since 1990, according to Bankwatch.

Bank branch closures cause severe hardship to customers irrespective of whether they reside in our capital cities or in regional or rural communities. The decision to close bank branches impacts particularly on our elderly and those who are disadvantaged by being disabled, unemployed or part of the ever increasing number of working poor. Some farmers and small business owners can also be described as `working poor'. They struggle to survive whilst living in poverty. It is these groups that are most disadvantaged by bank closures. Bank closures are part of the assault by economic rationalism and coalition governments on country Australia. They have gone hand in hand with the closure of country schools, hospitals, railway lines and vital state and federal public services. Each closure has pulled out vital services, jobs and pay packets and slashed at the viability of our small country towns. The assault continues with the coalition's plan to sell off the remainder of Telstra.

There is one bank that is addressing this problem, and every effectively. Which bank?—I hear somebody ask. The Bendigo Bank, of course. Bendigo Bank is Australia's only regionally based bank. Formed in 1858 as a building society, it converted to bank status in 1995, at which time it was Australia's oldest and Victoria's largest building society. Bendigo has declared a profit in each year of operation, even during the depressions of the 1890s and the 1930s. Bendigo Bank is a publicly listed company on the Australian Stock Exchange and is owned by more than 22,000 predominantly individual shareholders. It has total assets of more than $4.5 billion—total funds under management exceed $5 billion—and market capitalisation of more than $400 million. The company operates more than 100 branches and employs more than 1,000 staff.

Bendigo is a supplier of diverse financial and allied products with a strong customer service focus. Bank and subsidiary services include retail banking, commercial banking and finance, funds management, insurance, superannuation, trustee services and foreign exchange. The focus is on consumer markets and small to medium sized businesses. The group's operations are focused on Victoria. It operates branches and public agencies throughout Victoria and southern New South Wales, with outlets in each of Australia's mainland state capital cities. Business is also sourced through mobile banks and a network of referral agencies.

In January 1999, Bendigo Bank and Elders Australia began a joint venture company to deliver banking services to primary producers throughout rural Australia. The company marries Bendigo's banking expertise with Elders's distribution outlet of some 280 branches Australia-wide. In March 1999, the bank announced a joint venture with IOOF—Bendigo Investment Services—to deliver funds management and advisory services through the bank's branch network. As part of these alliances, both Elders and IOOF acquired substantial shareholdings in Bendigo Bank. Both companies now hold around six per cent of the bank's stock. In April 2000, the bank announced an alliance with Tasmanian Trustees to form a joint venture company to provide retail banking services throughout Tasmania.

In the same month, the bank announced an alliance with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia with a long-term aim to provide retail banking at pharmacies in communities not served by bank branches. In May 2000, the bank launched Australia's first ethical bank deposit fund with Ethical Investment Trust. This fund will benefit the work of Community Aid Abroad. In 1998, the bank devised and launched the innovative and exciting concept called Community Bank. This sees the Bendigo Bank partner local communities which operate franchised Bendigo Bank branches. Twenty-eight are currently open. A further 11 have been approved and are shortly to begin trading. The bank has received about 1,000 inquiries and expects between 50 and 60 Community Bank franchises to be in operation by the end of 2001. Local investors raise the start-up capital and become shareholders in their own banking venture. Bendigo Bank provides the banking infrastructure and coverage of its banking licence, and the community and the bank share the revenues. Shared responsibilities mean shared rewards. Profits made by the local company would be retained with the twin objectives of paying shareholders a reasonable return and reinvesting into local enterprise or community projects.

The first Bendigo Community Bank was established in the small Victorian communities of Rupanyup and Minyip. Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, you would be well aware of those small towns. I want to quote from a paper by Bendigo Bank managing director Rob Hunt, which illustrates perfectly the difficulties that small towns are forced into when the big banks pull out and the advantages of community banking to these small communities. Mr Hunt said:

quote.para: The last bank branches in Rupanyup and Minyip closed on the same February day in 1997, ending a century of branch banking in these neighbouring towns on the Victorian Wimmera's wheat plains. Rupanyup residents suddenly faced a 100km round-trip from `Rup' to Horsham to bank; Minyip's residents could head in the opposite direction for Warracknabeal, a mere 80m round-trip.

speech.para: You can imagine the inconvenience this caused most of the local residents, not to mention small businesses. Mr Hunt continued:

quote.para: Across Australia the stories were the same—people powerless to stem the outflow of government, local government and business services essential to modern living.

A 1996 study of NSW and Queensland towns which had lost bank branches brought the problem into stark focus. It affirmed that locals did indeed take their shopping with them when they banked—to the tune of around $4000 per head per annum. It also discovered unpredicted side-effects: credit was harder to obtain for locals and they were less likely to want to borrow, bad debts to local professionals increased and personal savings dropped dramatically. There was clearly a need for a banking solution which delivered both basic banking services and a commitment to local prosperity.

There are 1100 people in the `Rup/Minyip' catchment. Counting children as part of their parents' shareholding, no fewer than 750 have a direct stake in the success of their branch. Not surprisingly, given this level of participation in the venture, the business boomed. It reached its 12-month predicted business volumes in just seven months.

By the time its first anniversary rolled around, more than three-quarters of the local people were banking at `their bank branch', which had begun returning monthly operating surpluses. Five new jobs were created, business takings in the towns began to increase again (to the point where the Rupanyup supermarket expanded) and the community has a `can-do' attitude and is much better placed to produce better outcomes.
We believe successful communities create and attract successful enterprise and Rupanyup and Minyip have certainly improved their prospects of doing so.

speech.para: The Bendigo Bank's community bank is breathing new life into small communities where the service has been established. Most of these are turning a profit—sometimes of around $10,000 per month—in just 12 to 18 months. Other small businesses in these depressed areas are starting to grow again as a direct result of the presence of a local Bendigo Bank franchise in the community. It is also good business for the Bendigo Bank. Equally important is the sense of pride in these communities that is generated by owning and profitably operating their own bank, whose profits are returned directly to those communities. If the Howard government demonstrated even a tenth of the innovation, commitment and understanding of rural and regional Australia shown by the Bendigo Bank and the communities who are benefiting by the Bendigo franchises, regional Australia would not be in the difficulties we are in today.

The Bendigo Bank is also involved in a number of innovative products and services like the Bendigo Stock Exchange, a regional development fund, Bendigo telco, and a range of other services, all of which are aimed at enhancing the business sector in regional Australia. I will have more to say on these ventures at another time. If honourable members would like more information on the Bendigo community banking concept, they should contact the Bendigo Bank's Community Bank Development Team on 1300 361 911 or visit the bank's web site at www.bendigobank.com.au. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As members of parliament, we should have a clear set of priorities when Commonwealth budgets are framed. Simply put, how do you rate the importance of reducing debt, cutting tax or increasing government expenditure? I am on the side of, firstly, reducing debt and, secondly, cutting tax; and I think the third priority should be increasing government spending. They are the Liberal Party's priorities and the National Party's priorities, and they are the parameters that we operate within. The Labor Party, I think, would have an inverse set of priorities.

speech.para: We do not talk much about small government any more, but we should. In the area of health, much of the policy focus is directed towards the primary aim of constraining public expenditure on health. We have been very successful at this, keeping expenditure on health at about 8½ per cent of GDP, with life expectancy and health outcomes some of the best in the world. Medibank Private was established in 1976 in competition with private health funds. Since 1998 it has been separated from the Health Insurance Commission and made a public company wholly owned by the Commonwealth. It has 25.5 per cent of market share and is a not-for-profit organisation.

Given the success of the government's 30 per cent private health insurance rebate, and also Lifetime Health Cover, I do not see any reason why Medibank Private should remain in government hands. In the year 2000, we have the Chinese government and the government of Cuba privatising state-owned enterprises. There is no need for the Commonwealth of Australia to be in the private health business. Private health is already heavily regulated to ensure equity objectives so there is no need for a government insurer. At present, the government does not receive an income stream from Medibank Private. Medibank Private is a not-for-profit organisation. Another owner such as a bank or insurer may be able to provide economies of scale as well as complementary banking and insurance products.

As private health insurance is highly regulated, the removal of Medibank Private from government ownership is unlikely to have an effect on competition in the market. It has been estimated that it could raise about $350 million, the net value of its assets, or even up to $500 million or $1 billion. This is money that could be used to further reduce government debt. That would free up the money that we are spending on interest on our government debt, which would then be available for government expenditure. It would also help things like the Australian dollar, which is under so much pressure, by enhancing the government's fiscal credentials. Medibank Private at present is in a sound position, with profit of $57 million in 1998-99, which was 45 per cent of the total industry profit when Medibank Private is only 25 per cent of the industry.

The opposition to this view states that selling Medibank Private would send premiums through the roof. I do not buy that. A privatised Medibank Private would be constrained by the market. Over the last two years, since the government introduced our 30 per cent private health insurance rebate, we have seen negligible premium rises.

I stress this is a personal view. This is not a government view. I think it is an option worth exploring. I think the reasons why Medibank Private should be in government hands are no longer there and I would support examining the privatisation of Medibank Private.

talk.start.para: —This evening, I again raise in this House my grave concerns regarding bank closures by the big four banks in my electorate of Lowe. Associated with these concerns are the issues of bank fees, the remuneration of bank directors and the general distribution of banking services in Australia.

speech.para: Last Friday morning outside the National Australia Bank in Drummoyne, the shadow Treasurer, the Hon. Simon Crean, and the shadow minister for financial services and regulation, Senator Steve Conroy, joined me along with a large crowd of angry local residents in a demonstration against the closure of yet another bank branch in my electorate. We were also joined by Geoff Derrick, the New South Wales Secretary of the Finance Sector Union, Phil Davey and other representatives of the CFMEU, Drummoyne Councillor Angelo Tsirekas, Ashfield Councillor Emma Brooks-Maher, the Mayor of Concord and President of the Local Government Association, Councillor Peter Woods, Strathfield Councillor Andrew Ho and the President of the Homebush Main Street Committee, Mrs Marlene Doran. Nine bank branches from Drummoyne to Homebush have closed in Lowe since I became the member two years ago. The National Australia Bank boasts that it alone has closed some 88 branches over the last 12 months and that it intends to close a further 100 branches in the next year concomitant with a scandalous 50 per cent hike in its fees and charges. I would like to quote from a letter dated 16 October 2000 that I have received from Mr Peter Pilkington, President of the Strathfield Chamber of Commerce. The letter reads:

quote.para: We in the community felt the necessity to set up our own Community Bank because of the closures of so many bank branches, the total lack of services from the bank and the unreasonable charges levied by them. We hear consistently that the costs in savings are for the shareholders ... The shareholders that are benefiting from these changes are not the mum and dad shareholders but the directors of the banks e.g. Mr Joss of Westpac and Mr Smedley of Colonial State Bank who walked away with multi-millions of dollars in shares and rights ... We earnestly urge you and every Member of Parliament to get behind Community Banking as the best way to show the big banks that their customers are prepared to vote with their feet.

speech.para: What is the rationale behind these bank closures? The answer to this question is found in the two instruments that are relied upon by the banks and used in the moral justification of their actions: the Wallis report of 1997 and the Prices Surveillance Authority report of 1995. I have repeatedly called for the implementation of community service obligations for the banking industry. The reason for such community service obligations is that banks occupy a unique function in the economic freedom of persons to enjoy access to their own money. This is a fundamental right of every person. People should not have to pay to have access to their own money. People should not have to travel inordinate distances or use complex and inaccessible means to access their own money. Yet this is exactly what the banks demand and expect payment for—the privilege of access to our own money. The reports of the PSA in 1995 and the Wallis report in 1997 state that government should not impose a community service obligation. In particular, the PSA report specifically noted that the reasoning was that the major banks owe no special social or community service obligation to the community. The reasoning then was that regulation of bank fees and charges and minimum standards of `bricks and mortar' banking services was not necessary due to the emergence of a deregulated banking market and the technological advances in access to banking services. The PSA report states that:

quote.para: Governments directly address a comprehensive policy approach, including the issue of community service obligations, to the problem of essential services provision to remote communities, given trends of rationalisation of privately provided services (including banking) ...

speech.para: The gist of the PSA and Wallis reports was that community service obligations were financially `inefficient' and therefore should be rejected on this basis alone. Further, if minimum service standards were to be imposed by legislation then society generally should pay for this via the taxation system. In other words, it is being recommended that if we want bank branches back then we, the taxpayer, must pay for them. I note from the reports that these arguments apply equally to the provision of banking services in the cities. These arguments are false. They are false because they rely on the premise that the rationale for distribution of services refers to diseconomies suffered by remote banking or, in other words, that the assumptions underpinning the necessity for a community service obligation for remote banking areas were based on the marginal diseconomies of servicing remote areas—not metropolitan ones.

I am not the federal member for Parkes or Gwydir. I am the federal member for Lowe, a seat in the inner west of Australia's largest city. I do not represent the constituents of the town of my birth of Dunedoo, with a population of 800. I represent the residents of major urban areas such as Drummoyne, Five Dock, Strathfield, Homebush, Enfield, Burwood, Concord, Croydon, Haberfield, Ashfield and the City of Canada Bay. It appears that the diseconomies argument spares no-one any more. Under the rationales of the Wallis report and the PSA report, absolutely nothing is sacred any more. It is clear that the Wallis report and the PSA report never foresaw the day when metropolitan as well as regional branches would be closed in such large numbers. This trend of branch closures shocks the senses. It is a level of greed that has shocked an entire community, an entire nation.

It is not being suggested that rationalisation was good for remote branches but not for metropolitan branches. Rather, it is the extent to which this decimation of community service standards has been unleashed by the banks—and justified by the Wallis report—on all Australians, whether regional or metropolitan residents. This collapse of standards has clearly demonstrated the dishonesty that underpins the application of the findings of the Wallis and PSA reports in the conduct of the banks. What is this dishonesty? The dishonesty lies in the banks' use of this rationale to suit their immediate ends of profit taking. The banks have used the Wallis and PSA reports selectively, in relying on certain conclusions which are, I stress, based on specific presumptions. But these presumptions no longer apply.

What are those presumptions? The key presumption is that community service obligations specifically contemplate regional and remote services in their findings. The concept of a comprehensive policy approach did not envisage or recommend the wholesale collapse of bricks and mortar banking. That is drawing far too long a bow. Nor did these reports envisage the day when so many in our marginalised community would effectively be denied bricks and mortar in our banking services. Who are the marginalised and dispossessed? They are the frail, the aged, those without computer literacy skills, those who cannot use telephones easily, those who are economically precluded from holding small bank accounts, those who are unable to travel without some form of assistance and those small businesses who need banking services in their immediate vicinity. The list of dispossessed is large and growing. They are, to use the banks' own appalling language, `low value customers'.

In light of the fact that the underlying policy rationale for the conclusions in the Wallis and PSA reports has been fundamentally compromised, is it time to revisit their conclusions? I and my parliamentary colleagues Simon Crean and Stephen Conroy say yes. We call on the Howard government to immediately convene meetings with the banks and community groups and to begin work on establishing a social charter of community obligations. It is clear that the banks cannot be trusted to service minimum standards of community obligations. They have had their chance and they have betrayed the most vulnerable.

The banks are out of control. Jobs are being lost. Every premise that the banks make of a more robust, economically viable banking system is predicated on their lust for profit at any cost to the community. In fact, all talk about deregulated banking services and increased competition is a lie. Banking in Australia is a monopolistic oligarchy of four major banks totally dominating our economy and holding it to merciless ransom. These four banks make Ned Kelly look like Cinderella. The banks have demonstrated their contempt for low value customers, their love affair with the major corporate shareholding community and their love of fatter salaries, shareholdings and options for those executives and board directors. They are gangsters without guns.

I urge the Howard government to call for public meetings with a view to introducing genuine competition and competitiveness into the banking industry. The banks must be made accountable to their customers and we must ensure that the Howard government ensures that minimum standards of service are delivered to customers. Finally, I urge everyone to get behind people like Councillor Emma Brooks-Maher and Marlene Doran, who are pushing for the introduction of more community banks and more competition in the community so we can drive down bank fees and charges and make the banks accountable for the dishonesty that they are visiting on mainstream Australia.

talk.start.para: —One of the great pleasures involved in representing an electorate encompassing more than two million square kilometres and more than 90 per cent of the largest state in our federation is that every so often I have the opportunity of attending events like the Northern Australia Forum held at Katherine in the Northern Territory from the 19th to the 22nd of this month. The federal electorate of Kalgoorlie encompasses the Kimberley, Pilbara and Gascoyne regions of Western Australia in their entirety, so the forum was always relevant to the interests of a vast number of my constituents. During my visit to Katherine, I was very pleased to catch up with delegations from Wyndham, Derby, Broome, Port Hedland, Karratha and Carnarvon and to listen to their problems and suggestions for the future direction of community development in their regions.

speech.para: Residents of those areas of our country to the north of the Tropic of Capricorn can be characterised by their resolute and pragmatic approach to life and work in the face of numerous natural and man-made obstacles. The harsh extremes of the northern Australian climate—which range from extended periods with temperatures above the old century mark to the unrelenting storms and flooding of the annual wet, and include up to a dozen cyclones each year for good measure—are factors in need of constant accommodation by primary producers as well as those involved in mining operations, fishing fleets and transport. The fact too that a relatively small population is thinly dispersed over such a wide and, at times, inhospitable landscape also gives rise to unique difficulties in the provision of many basic services that residents in metropolitan areas take for granted. Despite these difficulties and obstacles, the peoples of Northern Australia are not in the business of begging for special handouts or of otherwise seeking special treatment on the basis of their residential address. They do, however, ask for a fair go from governments at all levels and of all persuasions to ensure that facilities and basic infrastructure in their regions are maintained at a consistently high standard.

During the Northern Australia Forum, this government received a great deal of positive feedback from constituents about the many initiatives we have put in place to redress the negative imbalances that exist between city and country living. I know that the regional services, territories and local government minister, Senator Ian Macdonald, has been heartened by the community response to forum sittings this year, as I have been. However, I want to use my time in today's grievance debate to urge my colleagues on this side of the House not to rest on their laurels, because there are still plenty of concerns in our northern zones that need to be addressed if we are to maintain the present goodwill that exists towards this government in country centres.

This government's record in terms of regional and remote area development is unparalleled in comparison to the 13 years of centralisation and neglect that characterised the Hawke-Keating administration. Recently, for instance, Senators Alston and Campbell announced a $150 million contract to provide untimed local phone calls throughout the extended telecommunications zones, while Dr Wooldridge announced the extension of the full Medicare rebate to cover consultations by `Other Medical Practitioners'. Additionally, a growing number of my constituents—not all, but I will say that the number is significant—have contacted me through surveys and direct correspondence to congratulate the government on the introduction of the new tax system. In fact, they say that the new system should have been brought in years ago.

However, in light of these developments, a universal concern to arise from the Northern Australia Forum was the progressive decline in the real value of taxation zone rebates. As most members of this House would be aware, zone rebates can be claimed by taxpayers who have lived in a remote region of Australia for at least six months. The rebates were designed to recognise the disadvantages faced by residents in these areas in terms of climate, isolation and the high cost of living, in comparison with other, more populous areas. When the zone rebate system was commenced in this country, the real value of the sum amounted to approximately five weeks pay per year. In the electorate of Kalgoorlie, where plenty of employment opportunities existed, this represented a considerable incentive, and the rebates made a tangible contribution during economic downturns such as the so-called recession we had to have. I am informed that these days the real value of the rebate amounts to around half a week's pay per year and is quickly swallowed up by higher commodity prices and the current price of fuel. So, even though residents of Australia's remote taxation zones are undoubtedly benefiting from the substantial income tax cuts which this government instituted to coincide with the introduction of the goods and services tax, inherent inequity continues to exist between the cost of city and country living.

I have said it before in this House, and I will say it again: the only way to fully and properly address this imbalance is to establish a taxation zone rebate scheme which genuinely and accurately reflects the differential between the cost of living in metropolitan areas and the cost of living in more remote rural areas. Currently, a single person living in the remote area zones with no dependent children will receive an annual rebate of just $338. This does not go very far when you consider that in some of the larger service towns within my electorate this will not even cover the extra cost of the daily newspaper for a year. I believe I have also raised before in this House the fact that housing in the major population towns in the electorate of Kalgoorlie is not only dearer than comparable housing in Perth; it is more expensive by a staggering 37 per cent.

The problem that I and my constituents see is that, while the implementation of the new tax system has resulted in lower prices for many items that were formerly afflicted by Labor's hidden wholesale sales taxes, the differential remains. I would even venture to say that in recent weeks, as increases in fuel prices have started to bite, it has widened. The amount of GST paid by remote area consumers is greater than that paid by city consumers, due to the already inflated base price, a price directly affected by transport costs and mark-up based on reduced turnover and lack of competition.

The major problems of northern and remote areas are the result of low population. At present, the great majority of towns are experiencing a continuing reduction of population. We, as a government, have to turn that around. In the past, the attraction of an extra five weeks pay a year encouraged employees to work in remote areas, and they and their families contributed to the collective wealth of the town. Now there is no real incentive. Labor's rotten FBT was the last straw; and unless we adopt policies to encourage people back, when comfortable city-centric Australians take their infrequent doses of real Australia there will be no-one left to pour the beer or the petrol.

In many respects, northern and remote areas of Australia are still developing and need to be classified as such. If special measures for funding allocation are not implemented, we will finish up with overflowing coastal cities and with increasing family breakdown as the remote area work force spend more time separated from their families, flying into and out of remote employment. A meaningful taxation zone rebate, paid only to taxpayers who are bona fide residents, would encourage population back, restore the viability of local businesses, reverse school closures and restore communities. The rebate system as it currently stands is not addressing the problem as it did when it was introduced. The towns that were populated on the basis of tax incentives have been let down by subsequent governments taking for granted the continued dedication of a remote population. Until such time as basic services of education, health, security and transportation are provided for all Australians, regardless of where they live, then special concessions regarding taxation must be made. Only then can we justifiably espouse `one vote, one value'.

The remaining population are becoming increasingly aware of the enormous financial contribution made to the nation by northern and remote Australia and are justifiably indignant about the lack of infrastructure. Their perception is that services are given to areas of greatest population regardless of need. Why shouldn't taxpayers expect equal service on the basis that they pay equal tax? The throw-away line that `if they don't like the bush, they should move to the city' is not good enough. What we need in rural Australia is population, and the only way to get that is with incentives and services. The message from the northern forum needs to be heard as a wake-up call for my city based southern colleagues. They often air a point of view that northern and remote Australia is the backside of Australia. Need I remind them of what may happen if the backside seizes up!

Regardless of my prima facie arguments when it comes to zone rebates, I do recognise that any solution to this problem will need to be thoroughly researched and analysed before it can be implemented without destroying the budget and consequently affecting the government's delivery of essential services to rural residents in other areas.

On 31 May in this place, I said that careful and meaningful consideration had to be given to the rebate scheme if the problem of the high cost of living in regional areas was to be addressed in a manner satisfactory to rural and remote residents. In the five months since then, despite the very successful introduction of the GST, I have seen nothing to change my opinion. I urge my colleagues on the front bench to consider this over the coming months as a matter of great urgency.

talk.start.para: —I rise to draw the attention of the House to the negative aspects of the GST, and I grieve for those affected. I am sure all MPs are being confronted with examples of these negative aspects, and I would hope that government MPs would also show a little bit of compassion and draw to the attention of this parliament examples of where the GST is hurting constituents in their electorates. I would like to air the grievances of a few constituents from my electorate. I believe that they represent a pretty good cross-section of our community. I refer firstly to an 82-year-old grandmother, who wrote to me in August:

quote.para: I am so disgusted and annoyed over the GST and what it is doing to us old age pensioners. All the great promises our Prime Minister made re what we were going to get ...

speech.para: Further on in her letter she wrote:

quote.para: Our phone bill over $6 more on our account because of the GST. But what I am so annoyed about I do a lot of knitting for kiddies wards 4 boxes for Baulkham Hills, Westmead and Blacktown [Hospitals] and got an order for 6 bed socks for an old age pensioner so had to go into Big W to get extra wool and I could not believe I got charged $4.04 on wool for the GST.

speech.para: This is the sort of volunteer, charitable work that is being punished by this government. While there are GST exemptions for registered charities, a large amount of charitable work is done by volunteers off their own bat and at their own expense. They are now being slugged with this unfair and despicable tax for simply trying to help.

The next constituent I refer to is a 58-year-old self-funded retiree who holds down a part-time position of 15 hours per week. His 57-year-old wife was until recently working part time but is now retired. This constituent wrote, in part:

quote.para: Not wishing to be cynical, we recently benefited greatly from the $5 each week in tax cuts. We chose self-support as there is no desire to become a burden on the social security system.

It came as a terrible shock to us to find that the funds invested through our cash-back annuity which amounted to our entire life savings have been effectively devalued by at least 2.3 per cent along with small but additional fund management fees.

It was a promise of the Prime Minister Mr John Howard that “no one would be worse off under the GST.” To my knowledge, members of the community have in some way been or will be compensated as a result of the tax changes.

We had expected to be included in the group of self-funded retirees who are to receive a one-off amount of compensation—this package does not appear to extend to those who have earned a small income of $1,000 and above in the past financial year.

speech.para: Self-funded retirees are finding it harder to make ends meet as a result of this government's decision not to compensate them adequately. We saw the one-off savings bonus just evaporate before our eyes. It obviously was not a `core' promise. When the Prime Minister says one thing repeatedly, only to then welsh on the deal, it is no wonder that our government and our profession are held in such low esteem by the general public.

I refer next to a constituent who was injured in a car accident. He received a court settlement of $90,000, with the economic loss component estimated at $45,000. The income test rate was set at $422.90 per week with the social security preclusion period to apply for 106 weeks, from 27 October 1999 to 6 November 2001. This period spans the introduction of the GST. I understand that the post-GST income test rate would be $543.63, which would, if applied to my constituent's case, reduce the preclusion period by some 16 or 17 weeks. All the advice that this constituent has received from Centrelink is to come back and see them if things are getting tight towards the end of the preclusion period.

This government is quick to jump all over anyone who claims even one dollar more than their entitlement, to the point of bringing criminal prosecutions for fraud against pensioners, even in some cases against the advice of Centrelink staff. Are they willing to go the other way and re-examine the issue of the preclusion period? No, they are not. And why? Because it might actually mean that someone is entitled to a payment a few weeks sooner than the government would like. This government has short arms and very deep pockets and would not shout in a shark attack when it comes to giving the battlers a fair deal.
My next example is expressed by a constituent who is an optometrist, and he has expressed his concern is to me this way:

quote.para: As one of your constituents I thought you might be interested in a copy of the fax I have sent to the Commissioner of Taxation. The implementation of this new tax system has left a lot to be desired. I don't blame the workers in the Tax Department for this. They have had to battle with an unruly monster of a tax that seemed to be revised daily leading to its implementation. However, it is very difficult to plan when not only did I not receive my business activities statement but I still don't know how much tax I have to pay under the PAYG instalments. It is now seven weeks into the new tax year. This situation is causing me stress as well as making budgeting impossible. If there is anything you could do, I would appreciate it.

speech.para: There is an appalling lack of information and help available for people trying to come to grips with the new tax system. I acknowledge that the government has done some work in this area and more advisers have been employed by the Taxation Office, but the delays are still too long and there is still far too much confusion over the implementation of this system.

This leads me to another constituent who contacted me last week. He is a tradesman and small business owner who is having trouble with his business activities statement. He contacted the tax office to seek assistance and was told that someone would contact him in about 10 days time to arrange an appointment where they would come to him and go through it with him. Ten days later, a tax officer did contact him. The only trouble was that the officer was in Newcastle and did not want to come all the way to Blacktown in Western Sydney to help out. That is when the constituent rang me in utter frustration, expecting another 10 days delay while someone else from the tax office might contact him. He was a bit worried that they might be from Adelaide or Perth.

I have also received a note from a tax accountant in my electorate who raises another GST problem for small businesspeople. He advises me that the federal government has claimed that more than two million businesses have applied for the ABN-GST but that a number of small businesses have lodged application forms without consulting an accountant and they now want to deregister from the GST. These small businesses have less than $50,000 turnover and GST registration is not compulsory, and they registered without understanding the consequences. If these small businesspeople register for the GST, they have to lodge returns quarterly. If they are registered for the ABN only, they do not have to lodge quarterly returns. The cost of seeing an accountant every three months might not be economical for them. This accountant suggested that the government should have an education program to advise small businesspeople how to get out of the GST if it is not appropriate for them. I see that the government introduced legislation during the last sitting week about this issue. This piece of catch-up legislation will still penalise the small businesses affected until at least the end of the year.

On a final note, there appears to be a problem in some shops where the price on the shelf is not the GST inclusive price. My own son-in-law purchased a suit which was one price on the shelf and then they added the GST at the checkout. Last time I looked, that was illegal. It is certainly something that people need to be made aware of.

That appears to be a fairly good cross-section of the Australian community: an 82-year-old grandmother, a self-funded retiree, a constituent injured in a car accident, an optometrist, a tradesperson and a tax accountant. I also include my own relative. That is not to mention the anecdotal evidence of small businesspeople who have been advised by their tax agent to get out of their business because it is too expensive for them to operate under the GST. I am sure that the examples that I have given are also being given to government members, but I doubt whether we will hear from them in the parliament because to do so would prove what the Labor Party has been saying all along, that the GST is an unfair tax.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —On 3 August this year, at the conclusion of the Australian Labor Party national conference in Hobart, the Leader of the Opposition announced its new policy for health care. Describing it as `Medicare after dark', the Leader of the Opposition outlined what the Labor Party would adopt as policy in that there would be a facility established to provide emergency access to general practitioners and nursing staff after hours. We were told that it would fund new after hours services by GPs to reduce long waiting times in emergency departments and that telephone services would be staffed by nurses under the supervision of doctors to provide 24-hour phone advice on medical problems and treatment options. In the Australian on 4 August, the Leader of the Opposition was quoted as saying:

quote.para: When fully developed, the after hours network could handle between two million and three million of the five million cases that emergency departments now deal with each year.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: This initiative would take pressure off emergency departments allowing them to concentrate on major cases such as car or work accidents.

speech.para: He further argued:

quote.para: This initiative would enable GPs to handle less serious medical cases such as asthma attack or a patient needing a tetanus injection.

speech.para: Firstly, if a person presents needing a tetanus injection and nothing else, the nursing staff provide that injection. The second thing is that the Leader of the Opposition clearly does not suffer from asthma. Anyone who does will tell you how frightening it can be and also how difficult it can be, especially for patients, to know just how severe the episode really is. The families of the 684 people who died from asthma in 1998 would certainly attest to that.

The Labor plan is also to fund and establish GP clinics in or around hospital emergency departments. What this really represents is a shift in costs from state governments to the Commonwealth. If the stated intention of reducing waiting times to less than an hour were achieved, demand would certainly increase with people more likely, not less likely, to present with relatively trivial complaints. If we want people treated in the community, why would you establish a system that would actually discourage that?

I have been able to examine some research that has been done on the use of emergency departments by Australians, in particular those using what Mr Beazley has described as less serious complaints for which they apparently should be seeing GPs. There are a number of things to understand. Firstly, the Australasian College of Emergency Medicine has developed what is described as a national triage system which goes from category 1 to category 5. Category 1 is the most serious, life threatening condition, category 5 is described as non-urgent and category 4 as semi-urgent.
